results.title: The Secret life of twins. Part two
results.creator_credit: Judith Bunting, Learning Channel and BBC
results.brief_description: The 1960’s saw a proliferation in what we would now deem as a socially reprehensible, separating twins for the purposes of scientific research. What these studies do reveal however, are interesting questions about nature versus nurture - is everything pre ordained in our genes, or is parenting and the home environment responsible for who we become as adults? Program two looks at twins Jenny and Margaret who are reunited after 58 years, and the two Jims, brought up in two different countries, one raised as a Jew, the other a Nazi, for answers to the nature versus nurture question. Also tests the theory of twin telepathy. Presented by Robert Winston.

results.title: Let's have a holiday
results.brief_description: Join the Silly Billies as they go on holiday to an amazing place called FUN FUN FUN. Once there you’ll see the Ashton Super Acrobats, play games and dance and sing. Songs on the video include: “The Water safety song”, “The Silly Billies song”, “Fun fun fun”, “The Boogie Woogie”, “Aussie rap”, “Miranda the Aussie kangaroo”, “The Electric crocodile”, “Dick the duck”, “Boxo the fox”, “Raise your hands and be happy”, “We can count to 20”, “Making up my milkshake” and “Ophelia the fairy”. Swimming coach Laurie Lawrence leads the children in “The Water safety song”.

results.title: A Cold war
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Dent, Lionheart TV International and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Time watch”.
Dr. Christopher Andrews unravels the complex origins of the Cold War. From the earliest days of the Bolshevik Revolution, he traces the growth of mutual distrust and fear between the Capitalist West and the world’s first Communist state - an uneasy coexistence during the inter-war years which finally ended in a complete divorce, dividing the post-war world into two camps and so threatening it with destruction.

results.title: Japan: Tokyo to Taiwan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lonely planet: the experience”.
Ian Wright conducts this Lonely planet tour of Japan, experiencing the bullet train at 160 miles per hour, having his fortune read at a Buddhist shrine, visiting the peace museum in Nagasaki, and soaking up the fantastic environment at the Aso Fire Festival.

results.title: The Loved ones [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Kate Hampel, Angela Borelli, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Victoria and Taxi Films
results.brief_description: A documentary film that provides an insight into the running of the Lort Smith Animal Hospital in North Melbourne, Victoria. Established in the 1930s, the Lort Smith is a well-known, well-respected Melbourne icon recognised for its wonderful service in the treatment of sick animals - its mission being that no sick animal will ever be turned away. However by the 1990s the hospital building, run-down and outdated, was reaching a crisis point. Its clients had risen to an almost unmanageable level, the budget was in deficit to a million dollars annually and staffing issues were becoming a major headache. Radical change was needed if the Lort Smith was to continue. In 1998, through Managing Director Dr Alan Lawther and his efforts, the Lort Smith Management Committee approved plans for the building of a new hospital. The next step was to raise the finance. Dr Lawther’s push for change extended to a more corporate and professional concept of fund-raising than had been practised in the past and also a rethinking on staff performance and salaries. The documentary features interviews with Dr Lawther, his staff and the Management Committee as well as an inside observation of clients and their pets and the hospital generally. NB: Some scenes may be considered distressing.

results.title: Moruroa: the big secret
results.creator_credit: Michael Daeron, Pointe du Jour, Arte and La Sept
results.brief_description: This award-winning documentary examines the destructive nature of nuclear bomb testing around Tahiti’s Moruroa Atoll by the French government. Since the 1960s the atoll has been the site of around 180 tests producing radiation levels 850 times greater than that created by the Hiroshima blast in 1945. Contrary to France’s claim that the tests posed no danger to the people of the region, the film reveals, through interviews with some of the 20,000 Tahitian workers employed at the test site, that radiation has had a devastating effect on their health and well being and that of their families. Although the French ceased testing in the Pacific in 1996, their decision to conduct a final series of tests in 1995 was greeted with worldwide condemnation. With one of the highest cancer rates in the world, Tahitians living in the area are still paying the price of the French military’s refusal to acknowledge their concerns. A study guide accompanies the film, which is suitable for secondary students, and teachers of Studies of Society and Environment, Pacific history, English issues, Geography and Environmental studies.

results.title: Man of Aran
results.creator_credit: Robert Joseph Flaherty and Gainsborough Pictures
results.brief_description: Robert Flaherty’s story of life on the sea stormed Isles of Aran, off the West Coast of Ireland. Produced in the early days of sound film, Flaherty tells his story simply and with great eloquence. His camera shows the daily events of life on the Isles - a profound and stirring drama of struggle against the elements. This struggle is caught and fixed again and again in images of women and boys against bleak land, vast threatening rocks or cloud-tossed sky, or of the fishermen’s boats lost to sight among heaving mountains of waves. Cinematography by Robert Flaherty.

results.title: 'round and 'round
results.creator_credit: Barbara Greene, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: When Alex Lawson, minister, came to Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, he recognized the need for a family self-help program. In cooperation with his parishioners, he organized the Minto Family Life Education Program. Through group meetings, they are learning new skills to help them restructure their lives and resolve personal problems. Though the people participating in this program live in a small Prairie town, their concerns are universal, like raising children, adolescence, loneliness, marital strife and alcoholism.

results.title: Nature of Australia : a portrait of the island continent: the sunburnt country
results.creator_credit: David Parer, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: In the arid heart of central Australia there is an abundance of wildlife that has uniquely adapted to the harsh conditions. This program looks at shinglebacks, lizards, the gibba bird, marsupial moles, parenti lizard, the thorny devil plus numerous other flora in the region. It also explores the formation of Lake Eyre and what impact the infrequent rain has on the environment when it buckets down. Narrated by Robyn Williams and based on the book written by John Vandenbeld.

results.title: Big brother of Christmas Island: Tai Ko Seng [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mathew Kelley, Samantha Kelley, Peter Du Cane and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This documentary explores the significant role Gordon Bennett played in the development of the union movement on Christmas Island. Bennett immigrated from England to Australia and quickly rose in the union ranks. In 1979 he arrived at Christmas Island to help the workers union improve worker conditions. He was responsible for significant changes and during his twelve years became a folk hero to the local inhabitants.
